user_review: I don't know why I didn't think to make a reservation with how popular this restaurant is but it was a weekday in Feb so I didn't think it would be busy. We arrived about an hour early and decided to wait in their sister restaurant Le Vin Papillon and have a glass of wine (also a great place!!). We went to Joe Beef just as they were opening and the waitress said they were booked with reservations so we couldn't even wait. Very disappointed, we stepped into the hallway to find another place to eat but then the waitress came back and told us if we could eat within 1 hour she could seat us at a larger table that had a reservation at 6 so we jumped on the opportunity. We ordered oysters to start which were very fresh. My boyfriend got the filet mignon and I got the beef tartare. My beef tartare was very flavorful and unexpectedly filling. The filet mignon was very tender. They had a great selection of wine and the staff is very knowledgeable about the list. Although we had make sure we were out in 1 hour, boy did we enjoy the hell out of our meal. I'm looking forward to the day I can return to this amazing restaurant.

Joe beef is a MTL institution and one of my favorite restaurants. As of the first week of May, Joe beef has returned for takeout amidst the covid-19 crisis. They have an awesome menu with lots of options from appetizers, to mains to sides to desserts. All of their dishes have minimal prep and instructions are on the website.We decided to try the homemade sauces with lentils, the lentil salad, the ribs and bread. Everything was absolutely delicious. I can't pick a favorite dish, I loved all of them equally! Their bread though, exceeded my expectations. I was expecting regular dinner rolls but these buns were magic! We also ordered their fruit and vegetables seeds as a gift for mother's day. Looking forward to seeing the results this summer.

Aaahhhleeeujahhh aaahhhleelujah! The AOILI is out of this world!!! Came here sat on the patio and trust me order the aoili and the smoked trout. The merengue dessert was unreal too. Second best dessert I ever had. I had the joe beef dinner and it was more of a roast than steak (more of a heads up if anything) but everything was amazing. Go here

Ugh the lobster spaghetti was so good! I wish I could say it wasn't so that I don't have a craving to go back all the time. And we also tried the new york steak, and a pasta dish with duck hearts. It was my first time having duck hearts but the taste was not at all overwhelming or gross. So happy with the quality of food here and the flavours they serve up. The boyfriend and I opted to order 2 separate desserts to share between us and they were really great too. The thing is that their menu often will change based on the season and what's available. The pricing too for that matter. I'm always budget-conscious and like knowing around how much I'll spend beforehand, so that was at first something that made me hesitate. But feel free to look around the at many menu pictures people have uploaded online. You can kind of gauge how much a particular dish would be. I was actually pleasantly surprised that the lobster spaghetti was cheaper than I had anticipated since I suppose the market price of lobster was more in season when I went.

I ate in their lovely garden outside. It was getting cold, but they had heating lamps, which was very appreciated.The service was excellent, the waitress had great wine recommendations. The decor was very scenic and romantic. Most importantly, the food was spot on. The lamb ribs and fries were my absolute favourite. The ribs were smoked with a nice dry rub and formed a crusty exterior, but the meat was melt-in-your-mouth. The beef tartare was perfectly seasoned, fresh, simple and highly recommended. The olive oil they used was excellent and had a nice bite at the end of it. The entrées were delicious, the oysters were very fresh.Last but not least, the desserts were heavenly. The pear chocolate tart and the stuffed rolls (see picture) were out of this world. It was worth every penny.

This place is most definitely not overhyped. The atmosphere is very relaxed, the wait staff are knowledgeable in everything they serve and will take you through the whole menu (as it's written on the wall and often not easy to read depending on where you're sitting), and make excellent recommendations.The smoked meat croquettes are a must have, and the lobster spaghetti is their signature dish for a reason. I hate lobster and I enjoyed it. I ordered the hanger steak, cooked to perfection with a gorgeous sauce that perfectly coated the meat. Only downside is the drinks. I'm a tequila lover and they don't really do your standard mixed drinks so I had a tequila sour which was basically just tequila on ice with a tiny spritz of lime juice.EDIT.... review number two... went with a new person this time around, made the reservation months ago via their website which took me to Bookenda. We arrive and they have no record of the reservation, saying that they haven't used Bookenda for months. Never the less, they gave us a table right away, which was so impressive! This time we had oysters, sturgeon croquettes, lobster spaghetti as appetizers, horse with bone marrow and radish, and a NY strip with cauliflower and curd cheese. Everything was spectacular! Cannot stress enough that this place is amazing.Review # 3... Joe Beef started doing take out in light of COVID. My friend and I placed our order online. Lamb, beef, bread and dessert. Everything comes pre-cooked and sealed with instructions on how to heat and plate. It was packaged so nicely with everything we would need, and, even though the meal wasn't quite as good as it would have been in the restaurant, it was a great Saturday night meal, and an awesome way to support this Montreal staple!

It is soooo hard to get a reservation at this place. I was lucky to find a spot for our anniversary. My husband ordered steak and they made truffle pasta for me which was delicious. Hubby loved the steak. He highly recommends checking this place out if you love steak.

A Canadian institution! When you have the kind of pedigree that Joe Beef has, it can be hard to live up to the lofty expectations, but I came away impressed!The lobster spaghetti blew all of us away and was the standout dish. The steak was a tad grizzly and fatty but the dry aged meaty flavor of the beef was amazing and the french fries were some of the best I've had.

Joe Beef was literally the restaurant highlight of my Montreal trip. I know that Anthony Bourdain (RIP) featured this on one of his shows, so I knew I had to watch it. The food and beer are locally sourced, which is a great way to help the town. I got the local beer which the waitress recommended and it was perfect. There is also an extensive wine list on the wall. The waitress was extremely helpful explaining the menu (which changes daily and listed on the wall and in French).

It's as good as they say it is! Joe Beef is a great place to go to when you want to indulge in great food and treat yourself to a delicious meal. It is crucial to make a reservation as early as possible since they are basically fully booked every single night. I waited until the date opened up on their reservation calendar to book a dinner for my husband and I. As we perused the menu on the chalkboard, it was hard to know what to get since everything looked and sounded good. The waitress was really helpful in describing the dishes we were interested in and also helped us in narrowing down to different choices. We shared a foie gras torchon with confit apples as the appetizer. I really enjoyed the pairing of the foie gras and the confit. I personally really love foie gras so any way it comes in I am pretty happy with. For mains, my husband got the braised oxtail with escargot and I got the lobster spaghetti. Both different, but packed with unique flavours that make you reach for a bite of each others even when you're too full. We loved the tenderness of the oxtail and the escargot. It was paired very well with vegetables and mashed potatoes on top. The lobster spaghetti was rich in all the right ways. It was tossed in a lobster bisque sauce and was amazing. We were too full for dessert, but the dessert on other tables looked good. The waitress was also very helpful in pairing drinks and had an excellent recommendation for a white wine with my lobster spaghetti. Would definitely recommend this place to people visiting Montreal or looking for a special place to celebrate!

This place is always fully booked three months in advance but it is absolutely worth it. Their menu changes based on what's in season. I've been three times and every time the food is cooked to perfection. Portions are generous and fairly priced.

What can I say that others haven't already? First, if you know you're going to be in Montreal at least three months in advance, then MAKE A RESERVATION! If it's more than three months out, then set an alert. I had a reservation for a group of 6 -- we showed up, waited about 5 minutes and then got seated. We definitely got some dirty looks from other people waiting who did not have reservations. But that's why you gotta make a reservation! We ordered: - Beef tartare with smoked eel: AMAZING- we were super tempted to get a second one. - Smoked meat croquettes: simply delightful- Oysters: PEI, beach gem, and chiasson. Can't go wrong with oysters.- Foie gras tarte: it was good but the jello type thing on top was weird and it just wasn't as good as I thought it would be. I would pass on this next time. - Fries with blue cheese: the fries here ARE SO GOOD- Lobster spaghetti: SUPER STAR YES! But also be careful - it's REALLY filling and rich, so pace yourself here! - Scallops fried in duck fat: So buttery and tender. Each scallops was also sitting on top of some sort of meat, and also had new potatoes -- a well balanced plate. - Duck: This was WONDERFUL. Perfectly rare/medium-rare cook, great sear, topped with an egg and some greens for balance. Great jus. They had so many other delicious sounding dishes too -- some that were a little more "out there" that I would have loved to try had my co-diners been more adventurous. All the drinks we ordered were great. The whole bill came out to about $480 canadian dollars for the 6 of us. What a steal for this level of dining!

This is definitely one of my favourite restaurants in Montreal. I've only been here three times but I thoroughly enjoyed it all three times. It's not cheap but I definitely recommend it for special occasions or for a fancy date. Reservations are hard to get so you have to reserve online many many weeks in advance. I took my boyfriend to Joe Beef for his birthday because he had never been before. I could only get reservations for 9 pm on a Tuesday night so I took whatever I could get. Everything was delicious! I remember back in the day they used to have the double down. Omg I used to love that! I love everything with foie gras! I am so bummed they removed it from the menu. I started with a Bloody Caesar. It comes with an oyster on top. So good! I then switched to red wine and it so good as well. Too bad they don't sell the wine at the SAQ. We got the tongue escargot entrée, the lobster pasta and horse meat with a side of fries. My boyfriend was worried that the tongue would taste weird or have a weird texture but it definitely did not. The meat was so tender.The lobster pasta is amazing and comes with a lot of lobster. It's very filling. The horse meat was also very delicious! My boyfriend realIy enjoyed this dish. I personally really enjoy horse meat as bad as that sounds. Oh try the fries! I love the dressing on top and the spicy mayo it comes with. We were too full for dessert so we didn't get any.  I highly recommend this restaurant! If you haven't been yet you need to go!

I really wanted to love this place as I read it was one of the top restaurants in Canada. It's good but not to die for- and here are my reasons why. It was hard to get a spot. In order for us to get a reservation we reserved 3 months in advanced and set an alarm on our phones the moment the reservation was available online. Despite being so strategic our reservation was only slotted for 9:30. Despite having a later seating they had everything on the menu except one dessert item. We ordered the lobster pasta- which we were told is always on the menu. Cote de beouf which was delightful and we opted for a side of fries. Because it was B.C. spot prawn season we also got an appetizer that featured the spot prawns and it was grilled which I thought was okay, but since they were fresh spot prawns I would have preferred to have it made a different way to have the freshness stand out.Overall the meal was great, but if you didn't get a reso when you visit Montreal I wouldn't sweat it as there are many lovely restaurants to go to as well!

This place is almost impossible to make reservations but we lucked out with a cancellation and got ourselves a spot for 5:30 pm.Duck tartare ($25)My first time having duck tartar and it was absolutely delicious! the meat was tender and it was mixed in with crispy duck skin which added excellent crunch in each bite. in the center was a piece of the duck liver essentially it was like a foiegras pate which smoothens out the texture with the meat.I'm normally not a fan of things with orange flavour but this orange touch added a nice citrus taste to the whole dish.Lobster spaghetti ($40)This is their signature dish. Pasta was aldente, sauce was rich and creamy, kind of reminded me of a carbonara tasted but mixed in with slight lobster taste I assume, which explains the light orange colour. You can evidently build pieces of the half lobster which is much better than having bits and pieces mixed into the pasta. Although I do wish there was more of a seafood lobstery taste in the pasta sauce.Seared quail with clams ($37)This dish was my least favorite. The clams were large and a bit too chewy. There were a couple of clams that were baked stuffed with bread crumbs and mixed spinach. The flavour and taste of the quail was good, meat was juicy, not dry at all. Sauce had a hint of of lemony taste. The price is expensive but the food quality was there and definitely worth the price giving it is Canada's #2 restaurant.Service was good, waiter was friendly and attentive.

Consistently rated one of the top restaurants in Canada ( i believe now it's 3), you really can't go wrong here.   This place is booked up months in advance, however use the Dinr app check everyday and you can get reservations when there are cancellations (that's what we did for same day reservations - we got lucky).We did have a late reservation - at 10:30pm...but ended up having to wait 25 min as the table wasn't done.  As there really isn't a waiting section, 2 of us waited in the front and the rest of the group outside.  Seeing this, staff gave me and my friend a free glass of wine.  We tried to decline saying they didn't need to, but the insisted :)   Service is really superb here!For our group (5), we decided to order a few dishes and share - the famous lobster spaghetti (I've had this before at their sister restaurant - Liverpool),  I found the portion smaller here and less saucy with less lobster pieces.  Still good though.Halibut cheeks and the hangar steak were both delicious.  Cooked perfectly, drowned in delicious sauces..I wished I was alone to lick my plate clean..lolHorse tartare - just needed a small piece - quite rich and heavy tasting - I would suggest this if a group of people want to share.  Couldn't imagine eating it on my own.  We also had a pesto and mozzarella ball dish - it was good, but I don't think you need to order this. Save your money and space in your tummy for other items.  Overall, this is a must do in Montreal.  It's expensive..but so worth the splurge.

Joe Beef is the King of Montreal restaurants and the #3 restaurant in the country for good reason. Like Liverpool House next door, they do certain things here that other restaurants cannot even approach. Their mission involves a deep respect for ingredients and an ever changing menu pushing the boundaries of food and broadening horizons. They believe in using the whole animal and serve a menu that is both rooted in classical French and Canadian traditions. Everything is very good. I know many people get a kick out of telling the waiter to "make it rain" thereby letting him/her design a tasting menu for you. While this option is appreciated, I prefer to order my own meal.My wife and I had a 5:30pm reservation this past Saturday night to celebrate our 5 year wedding anniversary. To even get a 5:30pm reservation (not ideal), I had to book it 3 months in advance.For the first 10 minutes, service was non-existent. All of the sudden however, our waiter and a team of no less than 3 other food-runners/busboys/sommeliers, burst into action pampering us for the next 2 hours and 45 minutes. They are very big on suggesting the food and wine you should have. We took some of their suggestions and ignored some others (particularly when it came to choosing wines). They put up with us and were extremely friendly all night long. The menus are not printed out and are only available on the chalkboard. As they change so often, I feel it is incumbent upon Yelp reviewers to post updated pictures every week so people can do a bit of prep work before showing up for dinner.I started with a classic bloody caesar while my wife got the Moscow mule which was not too sweet and very well balanced. The oyster served atop my caesar was so fresh and vibrant, we decided to order 6 more (oysters, not bloody caesars!)For appetizers we enjoyed the raw scallops served in a buttery lemon sauce with toasted almonds. These were so light and delicious, we ordered a second plate of them. I also tried the foie gras torchon with confit apples. It was tasty, but I would have thought they would serve some toasted bread along side it. We had already ordered some rye bread with a Moishes pickle (tasted like one..) but had polished off the plate before the fatty liver arrived.We also shared a small dish of roasted quail legs with some fresh calamari and white beans. It was slightly crispy and tasted like a classic barbecued chicken, only more rich and tender. This dish really shows how versatile Joe Beef is with their cooking techniques. It's one thing to master a dish and train people to prepare it properly with the right equipment. To show you can master about 25 different dishes every single week with the same finesse and respect for each new ingredient is completely revolutionary. For mains, I chose the duck magret served with a sausage made from duck heart. It was beyond delicious. You have got to trust these guys when eating here and throw away your hangups. The rewards are plentiful. The duck was cooked and sliced to a beautiful medium rare, while the sausage tasted rich and very flavourful (similar to brisket). The whole dish was coated in a rich sauce. We also split the classic Joe Beef fries which are done in beef fat and served with chopped garlic and mayo. These guys know their way around a french fry.For dessert we had the classic Marjolaine hazelnut layer cake which as advertised everywhere was next level delicious and rich. The stunner however was their homemade ice cream sundae of the week which is hard to describe. I think it had crumbled pistachios amongst other ingredients. Just look at my picture. I don't need to use words.To cap it off, during the meal, we noticed Mr. McMillan standing right by our table for a brief moment. With his heavily tattooed arms and newly slimmed frame, He stood there briefly with a quiet confidence to him. He seemed to be enjoying life, gazing at the packed room and what he had accomplished. I didn't bother him, but if he reads this, he and Fred should know how much respect and appreciation I have for them both.

While a Quebecois blizzard whirled just outside, my husband and I nestled into our window table in the original space in the restaurant.  Occasionally rubbing the glass to peer outside,  and our feet warmed by the heater near our ankles, we had a grand view of the spectacle that is Joe Beef.  When a restaurant has the reputation (#2 in Canada) that this one does, the atmosphere and the vibe are every bit as important as the food.  We taste with all our senses.  It's a marriage, in my view, of a truly spectacular experience.  It can be had eating bar food and street food as well, not just fine dining.  When it all flows, then it is a supreme experience .  Joe Beef delivers on all fronts.  Darkly lit, romantic, buzzing, and superior service set the mood for the main event, the food.  We started with escargot - so buttery - and shared an endive salad that was off the charts.  Two orders of croquettes de fromage just because I can't resist a croquette. My entree (plat) was piled high with buttery lobster carbonara and my husband's rare filet mignon with roasted baby potatoes and spinach was excellent.  Our taste buds were exploding, sharing bits of our own personal surf and turf.  Though we didn't have room, we ordered a slice of the 24 layer Marjolaine cake, with a dollop of vanilla ice cream.  It was not cloying sweet, but I would have preferred just a little more hazelnut chocolate with my espresso.  Our bill was quite high, notwithstanding two cocktails and two glasses of wine.  Joe Beef has been on my radar for over a decade, so it was worth the wait.  And the expense. Indulge yourselves!

We had a great time at Joe Beef. We opted to trust the waiter for the food we ordered. We had one pescatarian and one person who didn't eat shrimp, so they adapted their selection to fit our needs. Great service and wine pairings. Great ambiance, very cozy. We got a lot of plates so I can't list them all, but everything was definitely very good. However, I wouldn't give it 5 stars because only one plate surprised me. It was a sort of raw salmon with a butter sauce (appetizer), which was incredibly impressive. I also thought it lacked a bit of vegetable options / lighter plates. Lots of plates included meat - it made the meal become more 'heavy' than it should, in my opinion. I would have liked to eat more but felt full very fast. I'd go again for sure, but maybe ask for a lighter selection. The fact you have to make a reservation months ahead kind of creates over-expectation for what it is. It was great, but it wasn't a culinary discovery for me. I recommend it :)
Reserve this place way in advance and get ready to experience the most extraordinary dishes. Our table of 4 decided to trust the chef with the selection of our meals and it was a good choice

We had essentially planned an entire trip to Montreal around a reservation at Joe Beef, so to say there was a lot riding on the experience would be a serious understatement.It did not disappoint.We arrived right on time and were immediately shown to a sweet booth near the front of the restaurant. A quick perusal at the blackboard menu was a little overwhelming, to be honest, so when our waitress introduced herself, we decided to put ourselves in her hands and let her plan our meal.It turned out to be the exact right choice.We were ultimately given a multitude of amazing, flawless courses, starting with, quite literally, the best oysters I've ever eaten. I have no idea what they did differently to these things, but the oysters were far meatier and tastier than what I've come to expect. A seriously strong start.From there, we were taken through a journey in food, essentially. I'm not going to list everything we ate (because this review would become pages and pages long), but there were definitely several highlights I want to point out.One of the more impressive appetizers we received were the Croquettes d'anguille fumee de Kamouraska, which arrived to the table piping hot and filled with some kind of seafood. I easily could've gobbled up about a hundred of these things.We were also each given a bowl of their Soupe froide de petits pois & joues de fletan, which was essentially cold pea soup. I've had pea soup before but never at this level. The depth of flavor was absolutely incredible, and the pieces of seafood in there were pretty much perfect.Another astounding course was a dish comprised of sweetbreads and tongue, and good lord was this incredible. The thinly-sliced tongue was so tender and flavorful, while the deep-fried sweetbreads were nothing short of mindblowing and weren't, as I might have feared, dominated by that heavy, unpleasant mineral taste generally associated with this sort of thing.When we first began looking at the intimidating menu, we were all hoping to get the Spaghetti homard-lobster and when it arrived to the table, we were overjoyed (to put it mildly). And it was definitely worth the wait. Although the lobster itself wasn't exactly plentiful, the perfectly-cooked pasta was rich with flavor and intensity. This would've been a fine dish to just eat by oneself, that's for sure.From there, we were presented with a trio of meat courses - including rabbit and pork. To say that these were incredible would be putting it extremely mildly. The pork, especially, was cooked perfectly and contained a smoky, dry-aged flavor that I found irresistible.At this point, we were pretty much stuffed but the food kept coming. We received an amazing cheese plate packed with some of the best cheeses I've ever tasted, and, of course, a dessert course. I'll admit I wasn't super blown away by either of the desserts, but that might just be because I was impossibly full by that point.I want to also single out the efforts of our waitress, who was absolutely incredible all night and who took the time to explain our various courses and drink options. (Oh, we drank a *lot* too.)I can see why Joe Beef is considered one of the best restaurants in Canada, if not the world. They offer an experience that's pretty much unparalleled. I can't wait to go back.

Unfortunately had a very unpleasant experience here. Appetizers were mostly good - had the jello egg and foie gras. The egg dish tasted bland but the foie gras was amazing, but they only serve it with one piece of toast which is not nearly enough for the amount of foie gras. The mains were very disappointing. The fish came cold and I had to ask the waiter if it was supposed to be served cold - no it wasn't, he took it away to remake it. I had to sit and wait for it to be remade while my partner ate his main course. He ordered the lamb shoulder which was good but the portion was unreasonably big, a very heavy dish. When my fish finally arrived, it was great and the sauce was amazing however the clams that accompanied it were grainy, full of sand, which was gross. Since the restaurant is so big and popular now, no one cared about our negative experience.

My first visit to Joe Beef this weekend came with very high hopes provided by my boyfriend's constant raving about this place, however they managed to still blow me away. The food was absolutely amazing, unlike anything I've ever had. The staff work in such a seamless team structure that you are never in need of anything. To my amazement, every staff member was aware of what we had ordered and was able to make cutlery adjustments and wine suggestions based on their memorization of our choices. This level of attention to detail is what makes the entire experience one of a kind and so memorable!We ordered the "morilles farcies, bacon et ail des bois" and the horse tartare to start. The morels were out of this world, so flavourful! The tartare was also very good and beautifully prepared. For our mains I ordered the classic lobster spaghetti and my boyfriend ordered the pork shoulder, we were both incredibly happy with our choices! We finished the night with their amazing hazelnut layer cake, a classic French traditional desert. I cannot wait to return and will be suggesting this restaurant to anybody who is looking for an incredible meal with astounding service in Montreal.

When I saw two jolly guys on television traveling with their own stash of truffles on a train jaunt through the Québécois countryside, I knew I needed to visit whatever restaurant they were hawking on the show. "Those guys" were chef-owners David McMillan and Fred Morin and "that restaurant" turned out to be Joe Beef, so there I went on a recent trip to Montreal.Together Chefs McMillan and Morin co-helm this celebrated restaurant, opened in 2005 and inspired by Chef Martin Picard's Au Pied de Cochon and the bistros of Paris. Like neighboring Au Pied de Cochon, Joe Beef is dedicated to epic and excess eating and drinking. Few places in the world promote gluttony quite like Montreal, and Joe Beef definitely adds to if not helps lead the over-the-top food culture in this part of Canada.A clear theme of broadening horizons and embracing unusual ingredients was evident during my visit. First up was an appetizer of buffalo mozzarella with squash (mozzarella de buffalone), two foods I'm very fond of but had never eaten together. The dish highlighted squash in several forms: delicata rings, roasted butternut squash, butternut squash puree, and toasted pumpkin seeds all drizzled with a classic ravigote sauce. The char on the warm grilled vegetables worked insanely well with the cool, creamy mozzarella, a seeming study of contrasts that I would enjoy again any day.Yes folks, horse (filet de cheval) and eel (croquettes d'anguilles) were on the menu. I however went with a dish of pork shoulder, squid, and clams (echine de cochon, calmars, et palourdes) for my main entree, again an unexpected combination that worked surprisingly well in tandem. Pork is not normally my protein of choice, especially when there are several variations of beef on the menu, and especially not paired with seafood, but this particular preparation created a dish that I would most assuredly eat (inhale) again. Cooked for 48 hours, the pork was so tender that I thought I was chewing butter. The accompanying saffron-rich sauce was thick and decadent and contained no dairy, even though the creaminess factor would suggest otherwise. My dining partner meanwhile enjoyed a dish considered to be a Joe Beef staple--Spaghetti Homard-Lobster, served in a reduction of lobster cream sauce and bacon and featuring easily some of the freshest lobster I've tried anywhere.Dessert consisted of a chocolate tart (tarte au chocolat), served as chocolate ganache topped with whipped cream inside a flakey sweet pastry crust. Drinks at the beginning of the meal included rum-infused orange cocktails, a refreshing prelude to a most-fabulous and memorable meal. Much of the menu changes every 30 days or sometimes by the hour. Coming up with interesting menu combinations rooted in whatever happens to be available at the market on any given day is a testament to the experience and skill of the Joe Beef team, of which every member is an integral part of the operation. A job at Joe Beef, whether you're the head chef, operator of the fry station, or a member of the front-of-the-house staff is a long-term calling. This investment and professionalism is felt by customers in spades when servers can speak knowledgeably about dishes, since they've been briefed on every aspect of the menu and can therefore answer questions, talk about food preparation and ingredients, and make good recommendations as a result. Service during our meal was impeccable from start to finish.It goes without saying that what a restaurant puts out should be great, but in order to provide value and entice either the first-time visitor or the repeat guest, what they deliver in terms of food and service needs to be special and not something you can get anywhere else. Joe Beef delivers that sort of holistic "dining experience" and is most worthy of a stop, preferably several over the course of a lifetime.Pro-tip: Make sure to pay a visit to the little boy's or girl's room while you're here. You'll be kept company by a life-size buffalo while you tinkle.

The much recommended dinner came with a 7/10 score. The apply - veal liver with charcuterie sauce: intereting but over seasoned. The main - the infamous lobster spaghetti: perfectly poached lobster but under seasoned pasta. Highlights were the side of butternut squash gratin and dessert of poach pear with financier drizzled chocolate sauce and maple cream. The issue with the whole dinner was the service. I acknowledge that we don't speak French fluently but we try to throw in a few words here and there as recommended by other travelers. I was trying to order veal liver (foie) with veal tongue. He said something in French and asked both? We figured it was referring to the liver and the tongue. When an order of foie grad torching came, we were confused. We alerted our waiter and he became argumentative. From there on out, he never checked in with us nor serve any dishes other than when he came back to ask for our dessert order. When we received our bill, the torchon was still on the bill. It took us 10 minutes to flag him down and he apologize for the oversight. Also, one of the smaller washroom was nasty. Smells like a back alley.We would have given a higher rating if not for the subpar service we received. #overrated

***5 out of 5 stars***I heard a lot of positive reviews of Joe Beef, decided to make a reservation during my visit back to Montreal.  If you really want to go there, I suggest to make a reservation at least to 1-2 months in advance.  The place is really popular among locals and tourists!We arrived at 6:30 and the restaurant is already almost full.  Their entire menu and wine list is posted on the wall, so viewing was quite difficult as the dining room was quite dim.  We ordered a variety of appetizers, mains and desserts as we want to try out everything.Everything was excellent and description of each item we ordered is described in each pic!If you ever decide to go to Montreal, give this place a try, you will not be disappointed!

Eating here makes me want to go back to all my previous reviews and change any 5-Star rated restaurants to 3 stars, but that wouldn't be fair because not everyone can be held to the ultimate gold standard. And yes, this is it. Everything was so deliciously perfect, each bite was like the first. The place is cozy, totally unpretentious, with very friendly & helpful staff. The menu is on a chalkboard, in French only, but don't let that deter you if you can't read/speak French. The staff is so helpful and will provide great recommendations. I highly recommend splitting some apps and sharing a plate with a couple of sides. Try things you would never cook at home. Don't go with anything "safe". This is a place you go and trust the chefs...they know what they're doing. You will not regret anything about this experience. And if they still have the Beer Can Cauliflower on the menu THEN YOU GET THE BEER CAN CAULIFLOWER.

Food, service and staff all top notch!We let our kind server steer the entire meal for a group of six ; )He nailed it!  Delicious food, wine and cocktails!We know it's a team effort, so thanks to the ENTIRE staff for making us feel at home!
Everything I wanted in a dinner experience! There's no menu so everything we ordered came recommended by our waitress and our expectations were exceeded

I was super excited about the lobster pasta since half of these yelpers had recommended it. I ordered the lobster pasta and my husband ordered the steak, oysters, and fries. My lobster pasta was bland & looking back at the other yelp pictures, they also had only given me 3 small lobster pieces. For $44 that's pretty over priced. & my complaint is more so about the fact that the sauce wasn't all that tasty, so lobster was all I was able to eat.  My husband's steak and oysters were amazing though. The fries were tasty,but oily. Customer service was good BUT she didn't tell us what was on the full menu, as we heard the other waiter telling the group next to us about 10 dishes that she never mentioned.  I understand that we're Americans in Montreal and the whole menu was in French and servers  dont want to recite the whole menu to every American customer,but c'mon.  We got to hear about 1/4 of what was available.  So maybe it would be easier for everyone to have a menu in English also.

There's a reason this place finds itself on many lists for top restaurants in Canada. This was my second time here and it was still the same dining experience I remembered and loved. I was here with a group of 6 people. Because I'm the picky one in the group, I ordered my own food, while everyone else shared. Being a steak eater, I had to get the steak...and it was fantastic! I got an order of their delicious fried too. I did get to try some of the other plates that my friends shared. Everything was fantastic. I have to say the service is top notch. The waiter knew the menu inside out and described everything for us. He recommended a couple of great bottles of wine too that we shared. You are definitely taken care of when you're there. Have to add one more thing. The atmosphere in the restaurant is part of the dining experience. It's a cool, relaxed, and casual vibe...just a fun place to hang out for the 2-3 hours that you spend there. It's definitely NOT one of those pretentious restaurants that I'm not such a fan of. Definitely will be back!

Came here for dinner with a big group of new friends. We shared everything. We had oysters and clams, both of which were fresh and delicious. We shared the halibut, the presentation was phenomenal. It was so delicious and well cooked the skin was  flaky and so flavorful. We also shared the scallop appetizer, it may have been the best thing ever tasted. It was so rich and delightful. We had some other small dishes but those were the absolute highlights of the evening. The decor was quaint and charming with a natural burning fireplace. It's in a very cute neighborhood. Definitely check this place out!

Excellent food and great atmosphere!Waited 2 months to get a reservation and it was worth it! If I ever find myself in Montreal again, I will def eat here again!By the way, the dish I had reminded me of my favorite MRE; beef stew. Which got me through many a long arduous field ops and a kinetic combat deployment.Semper Squidelis!#fmfcorpsman

One of the beat meals of the year.We were only in town for one night & were told this was a must & our hotel concierge helped us get a reservation. We sat at the bar & the overall atmosphere was relaxed & friendly. Food was excellent. The menu had some interesting items I had never seen before. Service was great & our waiter was very knowledgeable helping pair wines with our food.Will definitely be back.

Highly recommended. Celebrating the end to a long semi shitty day. 2014 bandol. My first ever sea urchin. Really yummy.  Onglet (hanger steak) bordelaise sauce with marrow and escargot. Think this has become my new favorite restaurant!! Unassuming, kitch decor, chalk board menu... just makes you feel welcomed

Reserved my table at least 2 months ahead. I was really looking forward to my dinner! I was not disappointed!There's no actual menu. Everything is listed on a chalkboard. This is a bit inconvenient, as people sitting at the banquet won't be able to read it. So we actually have to move around to read what's on the menu and then go back to your seat. Since their menu changes, I suppose it's the best way for them... not for customers though.The service was great! All along, they made sure that everything was fine. They would change our plates/utensils between each dish to make our tasting experience better without contamination!Food was good! As entree, i tried the seared scallop and the smoke meat croquette. Both was amazing! As the main dish, of course we took the lobster spaghetti, it's as good as you can imagine! However, to eat that plate alone, I probably won't be able to finish it. The sauce was a but heavy. Also tried the deer neck with foie gras. I was disappointed with that dish. It was way too salty. Only took 2-3 bites and couldn't take it anymore. When you eat it along with some foie gras, the saltiness is a bit less bad... as of the dessert, it was amazing! Orange farci avec Five Alive. Basically sorbet in an orange with marshmallow on top! Very refreshing (especially after all the salt ingested...)! Was definitely a good pick!

Dear Mr. Beef,I usually don't write love letters to guys, especially guys with a last name of Beef but I'll make an exception for you, Joe. The dining experience I had at your place was a truly memorable. Maybe because I was on vacation and usually don't dine like this when at home, however the decor and vibe of the restaurant was special.  First of all, waiting for our table to be ready, we were guided to your rear patio next to the outdoor grill area where some of the meals are prepared to enjoy bottles of wine and cocktails.I couldn't help but notice your very own garden where I'm sure you grow the vegetables you use in your place. I'm sure if I searched closer I'd find some ganja trees, but no judgement here if there were. Your fine staff took care of us from the very beginning to the bittersweet end, even shared a few drinks with some of them in the middle of our dining experience and got to meet the chef you transported from NYC. We were happy with the variety of menu items we selected from your chalkboard menu, and although it was in French, that was fine since I polished up on my food items before my trip.From the appetizers including the salami whatever dish, lamb ragu, the bread with foie gras jelly, duck fat fries, the tiny fried fish. To the main dishes which included the lobster spaghetti and the grassfed bone-in semi-overpriced meat. Then the grand finale of the 4 course dessert menu which we could have passed on but so glad we didn't because it was the fitting way to close out the night.Mr. Beef, your name is perfect ... Don't ever change.  Well change just a little because if you stay the same, you know you're not growing. The only constant and life is change so keep it up and I'll be sure to come back next time I'm in Montreal.Merci beaucoup ...Je t'aime,Bong E.

The food here was spectacular. You can see the food being grilled in the back patio so instantly the smell was amazing. We tried a few dishes and enjoyed them all. The vibe is very homey despite being such a popular spot. Was on the pricier side but well worth it!

MUST TRY MONTREAL FOODIE PLEASURE:  THE MONTREAL BISTROThe late Bourdain ate then drank the night away with its chef.  Get the picture?  Chalk board menu, rustic, servers with tats, casual in a bad a$$ way but French at heart.  Oh, and it's ranked #3 top restaurant by Canada's 100 Best 2018.Note:  No printed menu.  The menu and wine list are hand written in FRENCH.  Forget Word Lens or Google Translate real time point and translate feature.  Learn some French, foodie.The menu is constantly changing based on availability of ingredients and the season.  There was no horse tenderloin on my visit.  Sigh. In true Montreal bistro style. the food is essentially French and dishes are stand alone complete with accompanying sides and sauce.  Portions are large.  Autumn brings game and the menu offered it in abundance.  A gamy yet sweet, dark and lean tartare of venison, a simple but sublime starter.  An excellent thick, meaty, dense, aged breast of duck finished in a creamy peppercorn sauce and topped by an egg.  The aging greatly concentrates the flavor of the duck,  as it's kept moist by an umami rich fat.  Finally a roasted guinea fowl with its just cooked, dark, gamy flesh also finishing with a hint of natural sweetness.It wouldn't be French without a silky smooth, foie torchon with apples, whole grain mustard and bitter dandelion greens.  The foie having a hint of sauternes that compliments the very mild livery taste and extreme fat content.  Finally, a large dish of braised oxtail and escargot finished in the classic escargot garlic, parsley butter.  Tender, light beef flavor indicative of Canadian beef, and just good eats.Very well chosen wines focusing on all regions of France.  All very approachable and pair well with the food.   Average bottle price, 70CAD.Servers look casual but know their stuff.  Zero complaints.Two month advance reservations required.A cutting edge bistro that speaks to Montreal.

What an amazing experience we had here at Joe Beef. Worth the hype and would give it 10 starts if I could. We went on a busy weekend evening and for sure, and despite reservations, had to still wait 30 minutes--it was not an issue. The service here is exceptional for such a delightful bistro. Additionally, the horse steak and horse sausage was amazing. Loved every bite.  Friend decided on the lobster spaghetti and had enough to take home. My husband had the lamb shoulder and was happy as well--overall, all of the food is exceptional. Ordered a few bottles of wine, decided that dessert was out of the question as we were stuffed. If you can, manage to snag a table here, go for it. Hard to manage as it is widely popular, but oh so worth it!

Okay, the food was all very delicious. Impeccably cooked and plated, however I must say that a dining experience is much more than just food. There were three major flaws with our evening, each worth a star in my opinion...1/ Our waiter. He did an extremely poor job of guiding us through the menu, seemingly satisfied with only recommending the most expensive items and bring them out to us in the quickest way possible. Since when is fine dining in Montréal meant to be a 'fast' food experience. He maybe spoke to us three times all night, and brought all of our dishes at once, without consideration of pace or pairing. 2/ The space. This was our second time to Joe Beef (we had an amazing meal last time we were here), but instead of being inside the restaurant we were placed outside in the shed. It was cold, bland and had all the ambiance of a Burger King. 3/ The music. The space might have been better if there wasn't dated, bad 90's tunes blaring above our heads. Maria Carey, seriously? I expect more for a restaurant that is supposedly one of the best in Montreal. Not worth the inconvenience not the money.

I had a super fun experience here! HIGHLY RECOMMENDED SITTING AT THE BAR!!! Our server Henri was perfect and was there every step of the way. We loved talking to all the floating servers about food and wine. These peeps really are passionate. We trusted Henri to build our experience, he was definitely a joe beef expert, and he was shucking oysters for the guests while helping us. He did more than just explain to us what the dishes are, but helped build our menu. We didnt know if we would have the chance to come back so we tried to order almost the whole menu, but after having a conversation with Henri and choosing a wine to set the tone, my boyfriend and i agreed to do a customized tasting menu per Henri's suggestion. He had a talk with the chef and he ordered the dishes for us with a few off menu items. We let them surprise us the whole way and it was a perfect journey.It was very cool to see how connected the serve staff is with the food. One of the servers explained that he and Henri fermented their own hot sauce for the oysters. So special! Began with some oysters and a few light, bright, high contrast seafood dishes. Pretty much the opposite of what i expected to enjoy here. The flavor combinations were smart. There was a swordfish sashimi/crudo dressed in a really herb-y mignonette, almost too acidic but then finished magically with brown butter. Who would have even thought this would work? Another favorite was uni and bonito and daikon sort of tartare. Ive worked with sushi for many years, Uni and bonito in my brain shouldnt work... but this ended up being my favorite dish. Moved onto bone marrow and beef tartare(tip: with the leftover marrow drizzle it on your tartare-you wont regret it!!) the ingredients and components seemed classic and simple, which is refreshing in a world of overly trendy restaurants trying to put hipster spins on classical dishes.  Finished with papardelle, duck and duck hearts, and oxtail. The kitchen even sent us a salad to contrast with all the heaviness- hey, they worry about our health sort of! That small touch is true hospitality. We took some joe beef fries back to our hotel and yes we were gross and enjoyed them for breakfast the next day. Still bomb. They also do smaller portions of desserts if you have trouble deciding. Sometimes the best journey means letting someone else drive the car for you. Thank you Henri!!

Your experience here is highly dependent on how good your server is at explaining the menu.  You WILL need the menu explained to you, even if you speak French.The problem is the menu is written in chalk on a giant blackboard on one wall.  In the evening, this blackboard is hard to read - nearly every patron takes out their smartphone and snaps a picture.  In addition to the menu being written in French, the actual menu items are often rather very poor descriptions of the food you will get, and you will have no idea how big the portions are, which vary greatly and are in no way related to the price you will pay.So you stare at the menu, puzzle out what you might want.  Then you ask the server to explain it to you, and it's like having a waiter give you the specials.  Except this time there are 15 things to remember.  I watched two other couples on either side of me suffer through this process after I did.The food is excellent, provided you get what you expect.  I've included some pictures of what I ordered, paid, and the translation from French to English where needed.The only disappointment was the Lobster spagehtti.  It's quite expensive for what it is.  In comparison, the other items are a bargain, especially for an American with the current Canadian dollar exchange rate.

Joe Beef is a fantastic dining experience and one worthy of its reputation. This place is in high demand and it can take months to get reservations here unless you know someone or get incredibly lucky from an opening and sliding in from the wait list. In my case, I booked my dining experience 3 months ahead and even the day the date I wanted, I was only given the option of the 9:15 PM seating.The incredible thing about this menu is that it's always changing and more than half the menu is different compared to what you read or look at pictures for. This is great in some ways and in other ways not so great if you want to try something you read or seen a picture of.We went with Oysters and a Mozzarella di Buffalo plate that came with a nutty chutney sauce for appetizers and they were great. The mignonette sauce that came with the Oysters was soooo great! The chutney sauce mixes so nicely with its nutty and warm taste vs the silky smooth fresh mozzarella. Both were big hits for us.For the main course we went with the plate for 2 Ribeye steak with side spaghetti squash and that plate knocked our socks off! That steak is baked to perfection and that squash made me re-think my opinion about squash. What. a. Plate!For dessert we went with their signaturelayered cake and ice cream sandwich and they were both misses for us. My Ice cream was sickly sweet.Service was great all night long, except for a late start. If my reservations are at 9:15... sitting down at 9:40 isn't an option. Don't allow that to happen. Our waiter was very good at his job and I marveled at his ability to remember the menu as well as he did.So the price-tag... yeah... this is a $$$$$ meal. Nothing I can't afford on special occasions but be mindful of that..

Everyone raves about this place so I was quite excited to try it. The food was indeed spectacular for the most part. We had the steak monsieur, the duck fat fries, lobster spaghetti, scallop appetizer and two NB oysters to finish. I'm not sure if it's worth the hype or the price point. I loved the scallops - it was one of the best I've had but I was quite disappointed by the lobster spaghetti since I had high hopes for it. The steak was delicious but I think I prefer some other steakhouses in Montreal better judging from just the quality of the steak.  Overall, I wasn't blown away by the experience but I have nothing negative to say. It is good food and the service was decent.

TL;DR Excellent bistro fare in the heart of Montreal There are only three possible excuses for not coming to Joe Beef1. You are claustrophobic - tight hallways and crammed table lead to a lot of elbow bumping. 2. You are vegan - while there were some veggie friendly dishes on the menu, the vast majority of the stars of the menu were meats and fish. Also, there's a real hunted buffalo head in the washroom. 3. You don't like spending lots of money on food - there's nothing on this menu that is cheap. Oysters 5/5 - The bully oysters were outstanding - the most fresh, juicy, plump oysters we've ever tasted. The sauces - cocktail, mignonette, picked horseradish were all great and homemade. Their hot sauce was just good. Croquette 3/5 - Just your ordinary croquette. The smoked sturgeon was a nice touch, but if we ate this at a local buffet, we wouldn't be surprised. Escargot soup 5/5 - This is our first time having escargot. The Appalachian soup was smooth and creamy, while not being heavy. The escargot was slightly saltier and provided the perfect chew. The meat was tender and juicy. Fluke 5/5 - The fluke came basked in a cream sauce with fennel oil alongside a slice of caramelized fennel. The meat came tender, as it was barely cooked. We could tell it had been poached lightly given how well the flavour of the fish had been retained. The fennel provided a striking counterpoint to the fishes gentle flavour. Veal 4/5 - The veal was crisp, with a soft, fatty interior. The sauce was TO DIE for. So creamy, flavourful and just damn meaty. The turnips were also divine, and treated with the utmost respect. The only component of this dish that gave us pause was the offal. We aren't used to eating sweat breads and liver, so we were a little overwhelmed by the taste. It wasn't bad by any means - there was just a lot of it.Duck 5/5 - This was our favourite dish of the night, for many reasons. The potato wedges seemed like an afterthought, but they were literally the best chips we have had in our entire lives. They were crispy beyond belief, and super fluffy on the inside. Perfectly seasoned as well in their special sauce. The duck was also perfectly cooked. The crispy skin was covered in an orange sauce made from wine and foie gras. The liver gave the sauce an incredible body that really brought everything together. The only criticism of this dish was that our piece of duck had a line of tendon in it, making some pieces slightly chewier than the others. Overall: Excellent, hearty food. You should go out of your way to eat here, especially if you enjoy meat or seafood. Get the chips.

I'm going to give 5 stars because the food is out of this world, but I wish I could give 4.5, because of an altercation I will explain more about at the end of my review.Everything we ordered was stellar. Started off with the $3.50 oysters, chebooktoosk from New Brunswick and point east from Prince Edward Island. They came with cocktail sauce, horseradish, and mignonette. Delicious. Then ordered the torchon de foie gras appetizer, which was served with apple, mustard seed, and dandelion greens. Very rich, but also very good. Tasted like fall on a plate.For dinner, had the roast beef, which was juicy, perfectly cooked and came with spinach and giant, crispy crunchy onion rings. Also the cod en croûte, which was served with potatoes and caviar in a colbert sauce. My oh my. In retrospect maybe I would have ordered a salad or something instead of the foie appetizer because everything we had was sooo rich, but that's my own fault. Not complaining! For dessert, the marjolaine cake. This is a MUST order. Out of this world. We mentioned when we sat down that we were celebrating my boyfriend's birthday, and they even bought it out with a sparkler candle. Very cute. Also, the servers here are very versed in wines and spirits. Feel free to let them take the reigns!I have to say, our server was PHENOMENAL. Informative, never rushed us, was friendly, paced our meal out perfectly - he was just great. He asked us what our likes and dislikes are, and helped us pick out what to order. Don't be scared if you don't speak French!However, if I could I would knock off half a point because there was an altercation at the table next to us (different server). The problem is that the tables here are sooo very close together, that we felt like we got trapped in the middle of this table's argument. If you have a table for 2, you are basically sitting on top of your neighbors. So, at one point, the couple sitting to one side of us misordered something. Side note, I will say was of no fault of the restaurant - I actually heard them order it - and (since the tables are so close together) I remember thinking to myself, 'I wonder how they will like it' because it was the same appetizer we had ordered. However, when it came out I guess it wasn't what they meant to order (there were multiple appetizers with foie), probably an honest mistake. But when they tried to send it back the waiter became VERY argumentative with them. I completely understand the waiter's frustration here, but he needed to handle it better. Yes this couple was also getting argumentative, and I'm pretty sure the order was right unless I also misheard it, but he was the one in the professional roll here. He was standing basically on top of our table while arguing with them for five minutes with voices being raised, and it was very uncomfortable and kind of a mood killer.

Listen if you're one of these people who didn't give this place an automatic 5 stars. Then just stay home, seriously. I've been waiting 10 years to eat here. I'm a huge fan of Anthony Bourdain (RIP) and after watching his relationship with the chef brothers who own this place grow on television all these many years and seasons, how could anyone not want to eat here? Ok so the menu board is written in French. So what. Learn French, you're in Montreal. Or have the wonderful waitress we had, who was so friendly and so cool, and who broke everything down. But it didn't matter because this was our one shot to order correctly so I just told her to take the wheel and she ordered so much of the food for us. And she nailed it. My only regret, we never got her name so we could properly thank her for her ever so perfect service. Here it goes. So my wife who isn't easily impressed by food, not because she's a snob but because she isn't a "foodie" (god I hate that word). When she took her first bite into those sea snails and I watched her eyes roll back into her head, I knew we hit pay dirt. She looked at me like she finally understood the meaning to life.Then we had the sweetbreads, another first for her, and we both were like what in the actual f... are we eating? How could food possibly be this good? Time for the main course. Cheval au Poivre, translation: Horse. Yup, Horse. When amI ever going to get to eat Horse again? So look. It's delicious. Only slightly game-y. Whatever cut we had was super tender. That bone marrow was heavenly. The fried duck egg on top help lend a little extra fat to the dish. What can I say, I like Horse now.Ok but that Beer Can Cauliflower, when I say this was the most delicious bite of food on the whole menu, it really was. I'm just going to leave that there. Order it. Thank you mystery waitress lady.My wife who would eat French fries her whole life for breakfast, lunch, and dinner told me without a doubt those were the best damn French Fries she has literally ever had in her whole damn life. I'm not much for dessert, but when at Joe Beef, you try to eat everything until you're about to explode. So I got the French Crueller with strawberries. And it was perfect. Simply that. Perfect.So that's all folks. Thanks for indulging. Sorry for the novel. I hope I eat here again. And if I do, I will be ever so grateful for the opportunity.

I was in Montreal for a conference and I had a reservation at the Liverpool House.  I wanted to pay homage to Anthony Bourdain, so as I arrived for my reservation, I waltzed into Joe Beef and asked if they had room for one....the Gods were smiling down on me, and I was seated at the bar.  I was able to have the host cancel my reservation at Liverpool House and was assured that there were no hard feelings.  First, the menu...it's on a chalkboard and written in French.  You're in Montreal...get used to it.  The bartender was incredibly helpful with helping me decipher some of the dishes.  I started my evening off with a Beef Tartare.  As expected, my tastebuds danced with glee as I devoured this entire plate of food.  There was so much flavor in this incredibly simple dish.  I was whisked back to Paris and envisioned sitting in a bistro with a view of the passers-by in St. Germaine each time I took a bite of this tartare.  I was unsure what to have for dinner, and the server asked what I think about horses.  I told him they were beautiful creatures, but I did not have any sort of physical attachment to them.  He suggested I get the "Chevral"....French for you guessed it...horse.  The chevral came galloping on a plate a short time later.  Y'all, the heavens opened up, angels sang, and I am pretty sure I saw Jesus.  I was served a horse medallion.  It was so tender, I did not even need a knife to cut it.  It was served over a potato pancake with a sauce that had bleu cheese in it.  I HATE bleu cheese, but everything worked!  It was one of THE BEST plates of food I have ever had.  Now...I understand that horses are often treated inhumanely before they are "disposed of" and there is quite a bit of controversy surrounding the consumption of horse meat.  That did not take away from how F*&&*^ delcious this plate of food was.  The service was amazing, the cocktails well priced and delicious.  I cannot wait to return!  You MUST go to this restaurant when you visit Montreal.  Make sure to make a reservation, in fact, book it well ahead of time (more than 1 month).  If you forget to, make sure to grab the DINR app, and it will notify you when an availability becomes available for same day dining.  Enjoy!
This place will haunt my dreams, i will crave every dish we enjoyed!!! Great service fresh ingredients creative and full of flavor!!

Following many visits to North America in over 30 years last night I enjoyed the best meal I've had. Sharing plates gave our party of four the opportunity to sample entrées: foie gras (silky smooth and so much taste!), papardelle lapin, stuffed zucchini flowers (OMG!) and tartare (delicate); mains: rabbit (best I've tasted EVER), fish (cooked to perfection), beef and lamb. I'm not a big fan of desserts but loved the custarde aux prunes and everybody else also enjoyed the layer cake. Quick mention about the service. Our waiter was immensely knowledgeable and really helpful in guiding us through the complex blackboard menus. Assisted us with matching wines. And it seems like all the service staff knew what we were having and worked together as a team. Assisted so much with our enjoyment. This place isn't cheap and our booking was for 9.45pm, finishing around midnight, but it is an investment in time and money that is more than worthwhile. Make Joe Beef your 'must go to' place when visiting Montreal. Book well in advance, book to eat late, grovel at the door to get in. Just go there!

Wow. The most incredible food/overall dining experience I could have asked for. Or waiter, David, was amazing. Super knowledgeable, great personality, super attentive. The menu was hard to read so we basically let David recommend dishes for us. We started out with smoked meat croquettes and a meat/mackerel spread on toast. It was all just great. For dinner, I ordered the roast duck with fois gras. It exceeded all expectations (which were very high) cooked perfectly and full of flavor. The roasted apples and potatoes were a nice touch. Hands down the best thing I ate in Montréal. My boyfriend had a steak (can't remember which) and French fries. All great! Steak was medium rare to rare which was wonderful. We ordered a delicious peach sorbet with shortbread for dessert which was fabulous. Overall, the best dining experience. Be sure to book reservations MONTHS in advance-it's worth it! No complaints whatsoever.

One of the best meals I've had in years.Came here for the Grand Prix weekend and somehow, my friend wrangled us a reservation, the first hurdle.  Apparently getting a seat here takes an act of whichever God(s) you worship and then some.  Once we got in, it was just enjoyment from start to finish.  We started with sparkling water and then worked our rusty French muscles to try and read the chalkboard menu--but don't worry, the staff are bilingual, and basically have the whole thing memorized anyway.  We enjoyed champagne with our meal, which consisted of a burrata salad with asparagus tips and caviar; handmade tortelloni filled with smoked beef and petits pois in a creamy sauce; hangar steak with chanterelles; rib eye; cheesecake with strawberries; a flute of creme anglaise, ice cream, a crumble top and lemon zest.Everything.  Was.  Delicious.  Look at my previous reviews--I don't just fling out five stars for any old place.  This was an absolutely exceptional dining experience.  The entrees (appetizers in French ) were the perfect little introduction with crisp, bright vegetables, and the tortelloni pasta was so tender with its smoked beef filling...melted in my mouth.  The main courses were both seared to perfection and totally rare/medium-rare as requested. My friend and I loved every bite of our desserts, practically wanting to lick the bowl clean (not terribly chic but we tried).  If you can get in, you must take your time and enjoy this place.  The perfect beginning to our awesome weekend.  Merci beaucoup!

Tip #1: Get Andy to be your server.  This girl is AWESOME. Joe Beef is notorious for its hype and reviews.  I was lucky enough to snag a reservation and boy, are we glad we got that reservation.  Like my tip above, we were greeted by our wonderful server, Andy, who apparently just started at Joe Beef.  Andy took us through the menu and talked about recommendations of what to eat and described each dish for us.  We ended up ordering the smoked meat croquettes (must eat), beef tartare, a beet tart (OMG YES, get that), a mackerel dish with caviar (yes yes yes!), lobster ravioli, fries, and a rum cake.  We. Regret. NOTHING. Everything was so fantastic from start to finish.  And the service we received from Andy was stellar.  She was funny, professional, and made awesome recommendations.  Joe Beef is definitely worth the hype and starred on our list of places that one MUST eat at in Montreal!
The best meal of my life. Also fantastic service, take any of their recommendations. Here's a tip, put yourself in the hands of your waitress or waiter

Came here for my birthday dinner in the middle of a very tiring week and I was excited because I had heard so many good things. Our reservation was late, i think 9pm or 9:30, and we arrived on time but still had to wait a while. They apologized and sent us to the bar which was a bit tight to wait at. I thought they were giving us a drink to compensate for the wait time but in the end we paid for them. It definitely got better from here though!The food was excellent. Between the two of us we shared a horse steak with an egg on top, smoked lamb shoulder with kale and lentils, venison tartare, foie gras and mashed potatoes with cheese curds. I had never had horse steak before, and although it was just a bit unevenly cooked it was mostly great. The lamb dish was borrowing flavors from southern American bbq (where I'm from) and it did it well.  And you can't go wrong with tartare, foie gras or cheesy mashed potatoes.  I know the lobster spaghetti is one of their most famous dishes, but there were too many interesting things on the menu. If I go back I would like to try it. The server was nice and helpful and although it's an upscale restaurant the ambiance is pretty casual and dark.

What a wonderful experience.  It all started with the staff.  Our waitress was absolutely amazing.  Super friendly and really gave us a detailed overview of the menu.  Here wine and food suggestions were spot on! Started off with smoked meat croquettes that were so tasty, so went for a second round.  Then had a pasta dish with mushrooms that was equally as good.  A blueberry frois gras was outstanding as well.  The main was the highlight.  The lamb was absolutely the best I have ever had.  Perfectly cooked and with a gravy so good I could have drank it.  I still saved room for dessert and that did not disappoint.  All in all one of the best meals ever.

Really enjoyable experience! I've been wanting to come, and finally snagged a spot (albeit at 9:30pm, but I didn't mind...I'll eat good food at any time of the day/night)! Their menu is on a large chalkboard, but luckily, I was seated right below it so it was easy to ruminate over what I wanted to pick. You can take a picture for ease of reference too. Service was really good; the waitresses were very nice and genuinely interested in whether the customer liked the dish or not. Mine checked up frequently, which was a nice touch. I asked mine what her favourite dishes were, and she was very persuasive! I tried 3 main plates and a beer (none of the appetizers seemed that amazing to me, haha). The chalkboard only had white and red wines (by the bottle) listed, so you have to ask the waitress for cocktails. Not sure if you can get the wines by the glass? It seemed to be only by the bottle. - Lobster spaghetti $38: a must-have. The spaghetti was still a bit firm, so it had a lot of bite. The sauce is RICH but also light; it tasted very seafood-ey and I asked for bread to soak it up (they don't automatically give you bread). There were 3 pieces of lobster which were tender and delicious. A nice light indulgence! - Smoked lamb shoulder with beets $37: WOW, super tender!!! There were 2 large pieces, beets, and some greens. The smokiness really added to the flavour of the lamb. - Horse tournedos $40: I've never tried horse before, so this was a must order for me, as I LOVE to try unique/rare/limited dishes. The horse itself was light-tasting, but still meaty. Although it didn't look huge, the portion was hearty since it's like eating a dense steak! The thick, rich, orangey sauce was savoury and with each bite I tried to get as much of it as possible onto the meat. I would say this is a must order, and I preferred it over the lamb! In general, the dishes were all made really well, although the presentation could be improved. It would also help if more details of the menu could be provided, such as a listing of the ingredients in each dish; on the chalkboard, only the major components of each dish are listed. The table next to me ordered the seafood platter, and were praising how fresh and delicious it was. I'll probably try that next time! I was too full for dessert, so that will also be for the next time. The atmosphere is quite dark but cozy, although it can get quite loud; I had to speak loudly to be heard, but it's definitely a lively environment!

I still can't stop talking about my experience here... the food was amazing the staff even better! We sat at the bar for my boyfriends birthday and had the pleasure of having Nelson as our waiter He was kind enough to explain every dish on the menu for us as they were all in French The food couldn't have been better and coming from New York wasn't too pricey I can't wait to visit again to come with my whole family

I had a couple hours to kill before my flight back to Toronto so I went back to an old favourite and was lucky to get a last min seat at the bar with a colleague The lobster spaghetti was outstanding and was the steak and frites. The foie gras was right of France. While controversial, I take to musings of my French friend, B. Who says, 'f$#k the ducks' If you haven't been, I'd recommend you tell the server what you like and let them build a tasting menu. Business or pleasure, it'll be culinary experience you won't soon forget

We had reservations for The Liverpool House at the bar for our anniversary, as Joe Beef was unavailable about two months out, but was able to get a last minute reservation. Hands down the best steak I've ever had, and the accompanying condiment was unbelievably good ( a shallot, caper, horseradish, blue cheese, anchovy concoction)If I can continue to get the in-laws to watch the kids for the weekend, this will become a tradition.

Pros Super awesome place the decor is relax like I'm at the country cottage .Food is superb everything melts in my mouth.Cons Price is decent but ask for the off menu specials they can be good but super pricey.

We were really happy & excited to finally go to Joe Beef.  Lots of hype and we were so entertained watching Joe Beef on Anthony Bourdain. We booked using the DINR app...the same day which was amazing! The ambiance was great, our table service was really good but the room is so dark that you can't read the chalk board menu...and it's all in French.  I think that may be by design.The menu items and the wine (based on your preferences) is communicated verbally, table-side...different method which made us feel like we were  being "guided" through the menu and more importantly, the wine list.  You're basically ordering blind in terms of price! The food...I'm a French trained chef so...I expected a lot!  The salads, the cook on my quail dish, the cook and flavours on my elder daughter's beef strip loin and my wife's lobster pasta were amazing!  Though, I had no sides with my quail?! My younger daughter's hanger steak was nicely cooked too, and flavoured nicely; the strips were cut too thick.  It was like chewing cud! At the end of the day, we were disappointed in Joe Beef.  So much so we will be canceling our reservation for their sister restaurant, Liverpool House.

When the food is as good as you were hoping for... I've been meaning to come here for years after seeing them on Anthony's shows and them being on Canada's top list for so long, but wasn't able to get a reservation on previous trips. My wife and I got lucky with wait list on a last minute trip and a dinner spot opened up. The wait was worth it and it did not disappoint! We went with our server's suggestions and almost everything was perfect. We loved the service and the food. Even though the "Beef" is what they're known for their seafood is phenomenal. The famous lobster pasta is as good as they say. And they're sorrel cream salmon was phenomenal.

Knowing that we were going to spend a night in Montreal, my PIC (partner in crime) mentioned Joe Beef.  I Yelped it, tried to get a table, no luck.  So I did a little research and found out that the best way to get a table is to call.  I was so happy to snag a reservation for a Saturday night diner.  As soon as we arrived, we were seated and were promptly attended to.  The restaurant isn't small but it's divided into a couple of dinning rooms and it's quite snug.  The decor is unique.  The menu is written on chalk boards that are posted but wasn't very easy to read because of the lighting and the angle we were sitting at, but our waiter went through the entire menu - he was very helpful. We ended ordering 3 appetizers- the sea urchin with the jalapeño aioli, Headcheese croquettes and the Scottish egg wrapped in smoked eel.  All the appetizers were good. For our main dishes we ordered the famous Lobster spaghetti, the sweetbreads with a side of foie gras and fries. The lobster spaghetti was "ordinary" IMO, nothing special about it and the sweetbreads had no flavor.  I was disappointed with both main courses.  Overall, Joe Beef is a great place to gather with good friends, have drinks and to share plates.  Reservations are highly recommended - be prepared for a wait and not much elbow space.

Fun experience with great service. Always busy so be prepared to wait even if you have a reservation. I had the lobster spaghetti which is considered a top dish. The pasta was cooked al denote, the sauce prepared in a beef reduction, and the lobster tender and succulent. Not sure if it matched the hype but only because the hype is ridiculous. I definitely suggest ordering however. The 24 layer chocolate cake for dessert was something I could have skipped. It's hard to hold a conversation here, at least near the bar. The true dining room is fine.

This was our most anticipated stop in Montreal and we made reservations a few weeks before we arrived.  We started off with a couple of cocktails which were delicious and well made.  We were lucky enough to have a view of the bar and watching the lone bartender make drinks, take food orders at the bar was quite a sight. There is massive wine by the bottle list on a chalkboard in the main dining room; by the glass isn't as extensive but has numerous choices.  Our waitress was friendly and enthusiastic and let us take our time in ordering and eating.  The menu is vast and written in French on the chalkboard.  Our waitress didn't go through each and every item, but asked us what we were in the mood for and our likes and then highlighted many of the items; maybe not completely optimal, but I didn't think we missed out on anything.Starters included the stuffed fried zucchini blossoms which were stuffed with smoked meat, sauerkraut and cheese; they were lightly battered and fried and were excellent.  Light even though the majority of ingredients were anything but.  Next up was veal tongue with tomatoes and shaved black truffles. I've had tongue before and it is normally sliced thin or chopped up; not this version.  It was served whole; yep just like a tongue looks.  Honestly I was a little taken back, but once I got past it and dug in I realized how good it was.  At this point (about 8pm) things seemed to have quieted down and tables emptied out; that didn't last long, that was the lull in between the early and late crowd.  Within minutes all seats were once again occupied; I can't imagine you can get in without a reservation.On to entrees we wanted the signature lobster spaghetti and another dish so our waitress suggested ordering a half portion of the spaghetti which was a great call.  The Lobster spaghetti was decadent and divine.  It was so creamy and satisfying that I wanted to keep eating it and almost wished we had a full order (which would have totally been a mistake).  We also got the chicken which was half a chicken that was roasted served along with clams and calamari; seemed like an odd combo, but it worked so well together.  The seafood was tender and the chicken was juicy and flavorful.  It was a sensational dish.For dessert we opt'd for the hazelnut layer cake which was light and not too sweet; it was a perfect ending.  Joe Beef lived up to the hype and I am so happy I was able to experience it.

After an anticipated 4 months wait time, I finally got a 6:15 pm reservation  at this local food Mecca. (I had a reservation for a month ago but it was a  9:15 pm slot- way too late if I'm going to indulge). Mind you,  I saw a man get a seat at the bar with no reservations! So there is a way to bypass the website for 1-2 ppl.It was an easy walk from the Lionel Groulx metro.
